_prev_prog_3.Description:
The key aspect of the ammonia storage emergency prevention program is based on operating and maintenance experience. As a result, periodic inspections of the ammonia storage facility are conducted, various stage ammonia detection/alarms are maintained in the nitriding department, emergency protective equipment is available for trained operating personnel use and an employee emergency evacuation procedure has also been established. A written emergency action plan is in place for the ammonia storage program.

INSPECTIONS  
- Nitriding department employees inspect the system daily for proper operation, monitoring equipment operation and problems (equipment/operating)
- Security guards check the ammonia storage tank room during each inside plant round inspection. Rounds are conducted approximately every 2 hours on second and third shifts and all shifts on weekends and holidays.
- Pre delivery inspection: Prior to acceptance of an ammonia delivery, two (2) maintenance employees conduct a visual inspection of the available capacity and the system components.
- Pressure Vessel Inspection: The ammonia storage tank is an ASME 250 PSI rated pressure vessel. As such, it is regulated by the PA Dept. of Labor and Industry as a pressure vessel. It is inspected by a certified boiler/pressure vessel inspector every three years.

INSTRUMENTATION AND ALARMS
A fixed ammonia detection system is located in the nitriding department between the storage tank and the furnaces directly above the dissociator. The detection system displays the measured ammonia concentration in ppm. Alarm systems are interlocked to provide several stages of notification based on concentration as follow:
- 12 ppm local alarm/flashing red light
- 25 ppm nitride department bell and crankshaft finishing department alarm
- 50 ppm alarm rings into security office

PROTECTION EQUIPMENT AND EVACUATION
All nitriding employees are included in the respiratory protection program. Two (2) 10 minute emergency escape breathing units are located in a labled storage cabinet east of the horizontal furnace in the nitriding department. These emergency breathing units are inspected monthly by the HR/Safety Department personnel. The emergency coordinator has authority to order a total evacuation of the plant in emergency situations in accordance with the ENF/ENC emergency evacuation plan. An initial evacuation will be ordered for any problem or minor emergency in the nitriding department involving ammonia - the initial area evaluated in this case is the nitriding furnace area, tool room, crankshaft finishing and shipping. A secondary evacuation will be ordered for any major emergency in the nitriding department or a catastrophic release of ammonia. The secondary area evacuated in this case is to be determined by the emergency coordinator and likely would include up to a total plant evacuation.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
INTRODUCTION

Ellwood National Crankshaft Company (ENC) operates a portion of a fully integrated manufacturer of specialty forged steel products, owned by the Ellwood Group, Inc. in Irvine, PA. Currently, the facility's core products are crankshafts used in larger diesel engines and pipe molds used as expendable tooling in the production of iron pipe for water transmission. The balance of production consists of other heavy industrial products that involve precision machining or proprietary boring/coring techniques.

The site is located on a single contiguous site with Ellwood National Forge (ENF) and Ellwood National Steel (ENS). The ENC/ENF/ENS site encompasses approximately 300 acres with 46 acres of developed property and 578,000 square feet under roof. The combined plant operations employ approximately 564 total personnel in manufacturing and administrative positions. The plant operates three shifts throughout the work week and conducts a one to two week plant maintenance shutdown annually in July. The maximum number of employees on-site at any one time is approximately 287 during the first, or daylight, shift.

1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT THE STATIONARY SOURCE

Employee and community health and safety and environmental protection are priorities of ENC/ENF/ENS and its management. ENC/ENF/ENS employs at least two full time health and safety professionals and retains other consultants and professionals as needed to provide supplemental services. Other staff are also involved in health and safety affairs on a part-time basis. The management and employees of ENC/ENF/ENS take pride in being ISO 9002 certified and the combined ENC/ENF/ENS facility is the recipient of multiple safety and environmental awards.

2. THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

a. PRIMARY ACTIVITIES 

This facility is a manufacturer of specialty forged steel products. Currently, the facility's core products are crankshafts used in larger d

iesel engines and pipe molds used as expendable tooling in the production of iron pipe for water transmission.

B. USE OF REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The RMP regulated substance  - anhydrous ammonia - is stored and utilized in the nitriding/surface hardening department of ENC. Anhydrous Ammonia is a toxic and buoyant gas with a threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds. In the nitriding department, crankshaft wear surfaces (bearing/throws) are heated in a nitrogen environment and nitrogen is absorbed in unmasked steel surfaces causing a case hardening to a prescribed depth based on temperature and exposure duration. Anhydrous ammonia is used as both the carrier gas for and the source of the nitrogen used in this process. The ammonia is thermally separated into elemental nitrogen and hydrogen and fed to the furnace to establish the inert nitrogen environment. Periodically, hydrogen and some nitrogen is vented to the atmosphere during the nitriding cycle and replaced.  

C. QUANTITIES HANDLED OR STORED

Anhydrous ammonia is transported and stored under pressure to maintain the ammonia in liquid form (under a vapor head space).  The ammonia is stored in a single 18,000 gallon horizontal, welded, steel, ASME certified, pressure tank. Administrative controls and operating procedures limit the maximum volume stored on site at any time to 16,200 gallons (92,178 lbs).

3. WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO

The ammonia release scenarios considered in the ENC RMP are consistent with the USEPA 2004 General Guidance Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accident Prevention (40 CFR Part 68). 

3a.  WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO

The worst-case release scenario for anhydrous ammonia assumes that the ammonia storage tank catastrophically ruptures, and the entire contents of the (administratively controlled) tank are released as a gas over 10 minutes. 

The quantity released (M) in the 10-minute event is calculated as: M = V * AC * D
Where V is the total volume of the

tank (18,000 gallons), AC is the administrative control on the tank (90%), and D is the density of the material stored (5.17 lb/gal or 38 lb/cf).Therefore, M = 18,000 gallons * 90% * 5.17 lb/gal = 83,754 lbs

3b. ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO

The alternative release scenario assumes the release of the entire (administratively controlled) contents of the tank due to a failure of a fill pipe, outside the tank enclosure. 

The rate of the release (Q2) is calculated as: Q2 = Cd * A * (2gh)^0.5
Where Cd is a dimensionless orifice coefficient (0.61); A is the area of the opening (0.0218 ft2); g is gravitational acceleration (32.2 ft/s2); and h is the pressure head exerted on the tank contents (262 ft). Therefore, Q2 = 0.61 * 0.0218 ft2* (2*32.2 ft/s2*262 ft)^0.5 = 1.73 cf/s (3,938 lb/min)

The time it takes for the entire contents of the tank to be release (t2) is calculated as: t2 = M / Q2 = 21 min.

3c. DISTANCES TO ENDPOINT

For both worst case and alternative release scenarios, RMP*Comp Version 1.07 was used to calculate the distances to the toxic endpoint (0.14 mg/1 or 200 ppm). Both model scenarios were considered as releases in urban areas, utilized the default atmospheric stability factors/wind speeds, and resulted in offsite impacts. Passive mitigation-release in an enclosure/building is applicable in either scenario but was not used in the alternative release case. Active mitigation available at the site includes water sprinklers to absorb released ammonia and detectors/alarms/operator attention to contain/control a release. However, no active mitigation was utilized in either scenario. 

The RMP*Comp calculated distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst case scenario is 2.6 miles, affecting an estimated population of 2,136, as well as schools, recreation areas, and the Allegheny National Forest. This distance represents the maximum downwind distance that the catastrophic release (under worst case weather conditions) could pose a hazard to the public. For the

alternative release scenario, the maximum calculated distance to the endpoint using the RMP*Comp model is a more realistic is 0.4 miles, which would affect an estimated population of 160, as well as the Allegheny National Forest. 

4. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

ENC operation and safety plans, policies, and prevention procedures as well as planned maintenance (overall management) have been established to minimize the potential for an accidental or catastrophic ammonia release. The storage tank is equipped with a high pressure, magnetically coupled sight gage that allows accurate tank volume measurement. In addition, the ammonia ordering policy minimizes the potentail for overfill, and unloading management procedures, which require two plumbers minimizes the potential for a release during a delivery.

5. 5-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

No releases of ammonia have occurred within the past five ye4ars that caused any onsite or offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place. 

6. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

ENC has prepared and implemented a written Safety Procedure (plant document sAw-004) entitled, Ammonia Emergency Response Plan, effective dated October 1, 2003 and a written Off-Site Response Plan (last update March 20, 2003) to deal with ammonia releases. ENC operations also require compliance and plans associated with OSHA, Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures (SPCC), Preparedness, Prevention and Control (PPC), the Clean Water Act (CWA), Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know (EPCRA), etc. Currently, ENC is up to date with all related plans and implementation of those plans. ENC has also prepared and implemented additional plant-wide policies/plans (e.g. a hot work permit program) and a Contractor Safety Program as part of the internal Continuous Plant Safety Awareness and Improvement Program.

The site response plan is registered with the Warren

County LEPC and is periodically implemented as a full-scale onsite drill. The last county wide ammonia disaster drill, which included the Warren County LEPC, local fire departments, EMS, and other emergency response personnel, was conducted on October 3, 1998. Multiple trained emergency response personnel are employed at ENC. Most recently (October 17, 2003), the emergency response team was updated/recertified by independent outside auditors as part of an annual program.

7. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

All facility ssafety progams, including the emergency response plan, are reviewed periodically for improvement opportunities.
